Title.evidence: Background: This study aimed to determine the incidence of postoperative cognitive dysfunction (POCD) in older adults using the Auto-MoCA application and to identify associated risk factors.

Trial_Design.evidence: Methods: This prospective cohort study was conducted at a university hospital in Bangkok, Thailand, from March to October 2024.

Participants.evidence: Participants were Thai-speaking patients aged 60 years or older scheduled for major elective surgery.

Objective.evidence: Background: This study aimed to determine the incidence of postoperative cognitive dysfunction (POCD) in older adults using the Auto-MoCA application and to identify associated risk factors.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Cognitive performance was assessed using the Auto-MoCA application preoperatively, and at 1 week and 3 months postoperatively.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 113 patients were enrolled, with 45 (39.8%) developing POCD at 1 week post-surgery.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Of these, 35 completed the 3-month follow-up, and 15 (42.9%) showed cognitive improvement.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The mean MoCA scores showed a slight decline at 1 week, with recovery close to preoperative levels by 3 months.
